Description: Large, heavy bronze axe-head: the cutting edge has been badly damaged by corrosion and there is considerable pitting elsewhere on the blade. It is attached by means of a plaited leather thong, now brittle and desiccated, to a short thick haft with faceted sides. The top and bottom of the haft are cone-shaped with flat ends. The haft is cracked just beneath the socket and has a large hole in its butt-end.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Qurna (Thebes), Believed to have been found in tomb of Nekht, Superintendent of Soldiers, Time of Rameses III. (said to be from)
Curator's comments: Radiocarbon analysis has indicated that the wood is ancient (c. 3270 ±120 BC) but not contemporary with the blade. Bibliography: 'Charles Hercules Read. A tribute on his retirement from the British Museum and a Record of the Chief Additions to the Department of British and Mediaeval Antiquities and Ethnography during his Keepership' (London, 1921), pl. II; E. Kühnert-Eggesbrecht, ‘Die Axt als Waffe und Werkzeug im alten Ägypten’ (Berlin, 1969), 112, G-X/2.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (122)
